{"step_by_step_thinking": "To determine if intensive chemotherapy is safe for rural cancer patients, we need to examine the relevant documents. Document [0] discusses a retrospective audit conducted at the Townsville Cancer Centre, where rural patients received intensive chemotherapy regimens at the same doses as urban patients. The audit found no increased morbidity or mortality in the rural patients. Document [1] compares the dose intensity and toxicity profiles of patients undergoing chemotherapy at the Townsville Cancer Centre with those treated in Mount Isa via teleoncology. The study found no significant differences in serious side effects, hospital admissions, or mortality between the two groups. Document [2] examines the implementation of a telechemotherapy model in North Queensland and concludes that the model is feasible with acceptable safety profiles. Based on these findings, it appears that intensive chemotherapy can be safe for rural cancer patients.", "answer_choice": "A"}
